Genuinely an unforgettable experience. The desolate and creepy, yet strangely inviting and nostalgic atmosphere of this game is still unmatched over a decade later. 
The word "liminal space" gets thrown around a lot lately, and it perfectly encapsulates this game. Take a screenshot from it, listen to the track "Self-Esteem Fund" from the Portal Soundtrack (which is free, by the way) and fucking ascend into the sixth dimension.

Portal is such a classic, had played it before years ago. But this was the first time, I actually finished it. The game is kinda short. But the bonus maps do add some decent extra playtime. I used a guide to finish them. But if I didn't. I think it would have doubled my hours played easily.

Por ser un juego del año 2007 y estar jugándolo por primera vez ahora en 2021, después de 14 años de su lanzamiento, puedo decir que es un juego que envejeció muy bien, las mecánicas se sienten fluidas, los textos siguen siendo divertidos y la jugabilidad está a la altura de cualquier juego de puzzle moderno. Super recomendado para jugar, aunque hayas nacido después del 2007, prueba juegos viejos pequeño niño rata, no te arrepentirás

I recently jumped back into this title and I'm happy to report it has held up really well in spite of its age.

This is a first-person puzzler in which the player shoots doors onto surfaces to get access to things that help achieve results. It's fair to call this game linear and aspects of it are dated but the graphics and fun with physics are unlike anything I've seen. I sorta remember this game being a tack-on for Half Life whereas Portal 2 was a full on game, but even so what Valve managed to do with this approach, story and cleverness really resonates for gamers - even years later. If it had a knock I'd say it's short, so you'll have to gauge whether the asking price meets your buy in point.

I did have issues with the user interface not scaling for modern resolutions and while the game tolerates a controller all the video hints are for mouse / keyboard configurations. Even so, I still feel like this is an experience worth having for anyone interested in puzzles, interesting story concepts, or just having a go at something that was revolutionary when it first came out.

Good game, I've replayed it a dozen times at this point, its a really fun game to just sit back and play. The puzzles are VERY simple, I don't really remember being troubled at all. Granted, I played Portal 2 first when I was young, and they practically use every puzzle in Portal 1 again in that plus some, so I was very familiar with many of them. So puzzles being as easy as they are can be good or bad, but the fun for me after finishing it once (which only took me around 20 minutes) is just replaying it over and over, I like finding ways to cheat the puzzles and all that, basically just speedrunning it but not actually trying to make a record or anything, just doing shit fast to do shit fast. A good time passer because its more laid back story.
